Office for National StatisticsFlexible census data

Overview

In the past, the Office for National Statistics (ONS) used a manual process to protect the confidentiality of data in census publications. They created separate datasets for different combinations of variables and specific geographical levels like local authorities or electoral wards. When it came to smaller areas where data disclosure was a concern, the ONS chose not to publish the data for the entire region. This was usually a problem in rural areas with a small population, but it was less of an issue in urban areas. Unfortunately, there was no system in place to address this, so users had to ask the ONS for customised tables, which added extra work for them and increased costs for the organisation.

A new service was proposed offering users a flexible way to access census data. Using Cantabular, backend software created by the Sensible Code Company. The goal was to develop a set of tools that enabled users to search the data with there chosen variables.

Challenges

The main challenges were to seamlessly integrate the system and user experience into the web architecture of ons.gov.uk, while also ensuring that users received adequate signposting and assistance in case they encountered any statistical disclosure control while using the service.

Mapping out a new service

I lead a discovery phase in collaboration with a user researcher, facilitating workshops with stakeholders and conducting research sessions with potential users. Through this process, we identified the key user needs and potential pain points.

We mapped out the user journeys with known personas across a task model, which helped us to visualise how the various products and services intersected across the website ecosystem.

Prioritising user needs

Based on the insights gathered during the discovery phase, we were able to identify and prioritise key user journeys. Using this information, I designed a variety of prototypes, which we then tested with users. The feedback we received during this phase allowed us to further refine the design and prioritise user stories for the development cycle.

A new service is launched

We made an effort to utilise components and patterns from the ONS design system. However, in certain situations, we had to develop new patterns that met the necessary accessibility requirements. To ensure compliance, we had these new patterns tested by the Digital Accessibility Centre. The service is currently in Beta and is available on the ONS website. Users are able to access more than 400 published datasets and can customise the geographies or variables based on their requirements. Alternatively, they can create their own datasets by adding variables. In cases where a user's query incurs statistical disclosure control, there are clear signposts to help them improve their results. Since its launch, the new service has been well received and has resulted in a reduced number of calls to Census Customer services. You can read more about New ways to access Census 2021 data on the ONS website.
